intro: Carya ovata var. carolinae-septentrionalis, commonly known as the northern hickory, is a deciduous tree native to the eastern United States. It belongs to the walnut family (Juglandaceae) and is characterized by its compound leaves and edible nuts. The tree typically grows to a height of 20–30 meters and thrives in well-drained soils. Its bark is thick and deeply furrowed, providing a distinctive appearance. The plant plays an important ecological role by supporting various wildlife species and contributing to forest biodiversity.
